column1: jeffwcpa 155465919830 "2017-01-06 03:58:15 GMT" https://jeffwcpa.tumblr.com/post/155465919830/the-ancient-peruvian-mystery-solved-from-space "garbagefingers: garbagefingers:  tlatollotl:  In one of the most arid regions in the world a series of carefully constructed
column2: spiralling holes form lines across the landscape. Known as puquios
column3: their origin has been a puzzle â€“ one that could only be solved from space. The holes are from the Nasca region of Peru â€“ an area famous for the Nasca lines
column4: several enormous geometric images carved into the landscape; immaculate archaeological evidence of ceremonial burials; and the rapid decline of this once flourishing society. What adds to the intrigue in the native ancient people of Nasca is how they were able to survive in an area where droughts can last for years at a time. The puquios were a â€œsophisticated hydraulic system constructed to retrieve water from underground aquifers
column5: â€ says Rosa Lasaponara of the Institute of Methodologies for Environmental Analysis
column6: in Italy. And they transformed this inhospitable region.   The funnel-like shape helped to draw the wind down into the underground canals    Lasaponara and her team studied the puquios using satellite imaging. From this
column7: the team were able to better understand how the puquios were distributed across the Nasca region
column8: and where they ran in relation to nearby settlements â€“ which are easier to date. â€œWhat is clearly evident today is that the puquio system must have been much more developed than it appears today
column9: â€ says Lasaponara. â€œExploiting an inexhaustible water supply throughout the year the puquio system contributed to an intensive agriculture of the valleys in one of the most arid places in the world.â€ A series of canals brought the water
column11: to the areas where it was needed; anything left was stored in surface reservoirs. To help keep it moving
column12: chimneys were excavated above the canals in the shape of corkscrewing funnels. These funnels let wind into the canals
column13: which forced the water through the system. â€œThe puquios were the most ambitious hydraulic project in the Nasca area and made water available for the whole year
column14: not only for agriculture and irrigation but also for domestic needs
column16: who has written about her satellite studies in Ancient Nasca World: New Insights from Science and Archaeology
column17: which is due to be published later this year. The origin of the puquios has remained a mystery to researchers because it was not possible to use traditional carbon dating techniques on the tunnels. Nor did the Nasca leave any clues as to their origin. Like many other South American cultures they had no writing system.   Some think the famous â€˜Nasca linesâ€™ related to the presence of water     Their existence tells us something remarkable about the people who lived in the Nasca region from before 1
column18: 000 BC to AD750. â€œThe construction of the puquios involved the use of particularly specialised technology
column19: â€ says Lasaponara. Not only did the builders of the puquios need a deep understanding of the geology of the area and annual variations in water availability
column20: maintaining the canals was a technical challenge as they spread across tectonic faults.   â€œWhat is really impressive is the great efforts
column21: organisation and cooperation required for their construction and regular maintenance
column22: â€ she says. That meant a regular dependable water supply for centuries
column23: in an area thatâ€™s one of the most arid places on Earth. â€œMaintenance was likely based on a collaborative and socially organised system
column24: similar to that adopted for the construction of the famous â€™Nasca linesâ€˜ which in some cases are clearly related to the presence of water.â€ The quality of construction was so good
column25: that some of the puquios still function today. These structures show the native people of the Nasca basin were not only highly organised
column26: but that their society was structured in a hierarchy
column27: says Lasaponara. She says the puquios were vital in â€œcontrolling water distribution by those in power over the communities that came under their influence.â€ Knowing how to bring water to one of the driest places on earth means that you hold the very key to life itself.  Why canâ€™t I read historical fiction about this.  ^^^^ Iâ€™m still wondering They built an elaborate irritation system over a thousand years ago. We elected trump." False link

jeffwcpa 153383253025 "2016-11-19 13:55:24 GMT" https://jeffwcpa.tumblr.com/post/153383253025/words-that-survived-by-getting-fossilized-in "scarran: yer-so-bad-best-thing-i-ever-had:  nevver:  wend You rarely see a â€œwendâ€ without a â€œway.â€ You can wend your way through a crowd or down a hill
column2: but no one wends to bed or to school. However
column3: there was a time when English speakers would wend to all kinds of places. â€œWendâ€ was just another word for â€œgoâ€ in Old English. The past tense of â€œwendâ€ was â€œwentâ€ and the past tense of â€œgoâ€ was â€œgaed.â€ People used both until the 15th century
column4: when â€œgoâ€ became the preferred verb
column5: except in the past tense where â€œwentâ€ hung on
column6: leaving us with an outrageously irregular verb.   deserts The â€œdesertâ€ from the phrase â€œjust desertsâ€ is not the dry and sandy kind
column7: nor the sweet post-dinner kind. It comes from an Old French word for â€œdeserve
column8: â€ and it was used in English from the 13th century to mean â€œthat which is deserved.â€ When you get your just deserts
column9: you get your due. In some cases
column10: that may mean you also get dessert
column11: a word that comes from a later French borrowing.   eke If we see â€œekeâ€ at all these days
column12: itâ€™s when we â€œeke outâ€ a living
column13: but it comes from an old verb meaning to add
column15: or grow. Itâ€™s the same word that gave us â€œeke-nameâ€ for â€œadditional name
column17: through misanalysis of â€œan eke-nameâ€ became â€œnickname.â€   sleight â€œSleight of handâ€ is one tricky phrase. â€œSleightâ€ is often miswritten as â€œslightâ€ and for good reason. Not only does the expression convey an image of light
column19: which fits well with the smallness implied by â€œslight
column20: â€ but an alternate expression for the concept is â€œlegerdemain
column21: â€ from the French lÃ©ger de main
column23: â€œlight of hand.â€ â€œSleightâ€ comes from a different source
column24: a Middle English word meaning â€œcunningâ€ or â€œtrickery.â€ Itâ€™s a wily little word that lives up to its name.    roughshod Nowadays we see this word in the expression â€œto run/ride roughshodâ€ over somebody or something
column25: meaning to tyrannize or treat harshly. It came about as a way to describe the 17th century version of snow tires. A â€œrough-shodâ€ horse had its shoes attached with protruding nail heads in order to get a better grip on slippery roads. It was great for keeping the horse on its feet
column26: but not so great for anyone the horse might step on.   fro The â€œfroâ€ in â€œto and froâ€ is a fossilized remnant of a Northern English or Scottish way of pronouncing â€œfrom.â€ It was also part of other expressions that didnâ€™t stick around
column29: and â€œof or froâ€ (for or against).   hue The â€œhueâ€ of â€œhue and cry
column30: â€ the expression for the noisy clamor of a crowd
column31: is not the same â€œhueâ€ as the term we use for color. The color one comes from the Old English word hÃ­ew
column32: for â€œappearance.â€ This hue comes from the Old French hu or heu
column34: like â€œhoot.â€   lurch When you leave someone â€œin the lurch
column35: â€ you leave them in a jam
column36: in a difficult position. But while getting left in the lurch may leave you staggering around and feeling off-balance
column37: the â€œlurchâ€ in this expression has a different origin than the staggery one. The balance-related lurch comes from nautical vocabulary
column38: while the lurch you get left in comes from an old French backgammon-style game called lourche. Lurch became a general term for the situation of beating your opponent by a huge score. By extension it came to stand for the state of getting the better of someone or cheating them.   umbrage â€œUmbrageâ€ comes from the Old French ombrage (shade
column40: and it was once used to talk about actual shade from the sun. It took on various figurative meanings having to do with doubt and suspicion or the giving and taking of offense. To give umbrage was to offend someone
column42: these days when we see the term â€œumbrageâ€ at all
column43: it is more likely to be because someone is taking
column44: rather than giving it.   shrift We might not know what a shrift is anymore
column45: but we know we donâ€™t want to get a short one. â€œShriftâ€ was a word for a confession
column46: something it seems we might want to keep short
column47: or a penance imposed by a priest
column48: something we would definitely want to keep short. But the phrase â€œshort shriftâ€ came from the practice of allowing a little time for the condemned to make a confession before being executed. So in that context
column49: shorter was not better.    I love this stuff.  I love linguistics. " False link
